Browse the source code of netbsd/external/ibm-public/postfix/dist/src/global/mail_stream.c

1/* $NetBSD: mail_stream.c,v 1.2 2017/02/14 01:16:45 christos Exp $ */
2
3/*++
4/* NAME
5/* mail_stream 3
6/* SUMMARY
7/* mail stream management
8/* SYNOPSIS
9/* #include <mail_stream.h>
10/*
11/* typedef struct {
12/* .in +4
13/* VSTREAM *stream; /* read/write stream */
14/* char *id; /* queue ID */
15/* struct timeval ctime; /* create time */
16/* private members...
17/* .in -4
18/* } MAIL_STREAM;
19/*
20/* MAIL_STREAM *mail_stream_file(queue, class, service, mode)
21/* const char *queue;
22/* const char *class;
23/* const char *service;
24/* int mode;
25/*
26/* MAIL_STREAM *mail_stream_service(class, service)
27/* const char *class;
28/* const char *service;
29/*
30/* MAIL_STREAM *mail_stream_command(command)
31/* const char *command;
32/*
33/* void mail_stream_cleanup(info)
34/* MAIL_STREAM *info;
35/*
36/* int mail_stream_finish(info, why)
37/* MAIL_STREAM *info;
38/* VSTRING *why;
39/*
40/* void mail_stream_ctl(info, op, ...)
41/* MAIL_STREAM *info;
42/* int op;
43/* DESCRIPTION
44/* This module provides a generic interface to Postfix queue file
45/* format messages to file, to Postfix server, or to external command.
46/* The routines that open a stream return a handle with an initialized
47/* stream and queue id member. The handle is either given to a cleanup
48/* routine, to dispose of a failed request, or to a finish routine, to
49/* complete the request.
50/*
51/* mail_stream_file() opens a mail stream to a newly-created file and
52/* arranges for trigger delivery at finish time. This call never fails.
53/* But it may take forever. The mode argument specifies additional
54/* file permissions that will be OR-ed in when the file is finished.
55/* While embryonic files have mode 0600, finished files have mode 0700.
56/*
57/* mail_stream_command() opens a mail stream to external command,
58/* and receives queue ID information from the command. The result
59/* is a null pointer when the initial handshake fails. The command
60/* is given to the shell only when necessary. At finish time, the
61/* command is expected to send a completion status.
62/*
63/* mail_stream_service() opens a mail stream to Postfix service,
64/* and receives queue ID information from the command. The result
65/* is a null pointer when the initial handshake fails. At finish
66/* time, the daemon is expected to send a completion status.
67/*
68/* mail_stream_cleanup() cancels the operation that was started with
69/* any of the mail_stream_xxx() routines, and destroys the argument.
70/* It is up to the caller to remove incomplete file objects.
71/*
72/* mail_stream_finish() completes the operation that was started with
73/* any of the mail_stream_xxx() routines, and destroys the argument.
74/* The result is any of the status codes defined in <cleanup_user.h>.
75/* It is up to the caller to remove incomplete file objects.
76/* The why argument can be a null pointer.
77/*
78/* mail_stream_ctl() selectively overrides information that
79/* was specified with mail_stream_file(); none of the attributes
80/* are applicable for other mail stream types. The arguments
81/* are a list macros with arguments, terminated with
82/* CA_MAIL_STREAM_CTL_END which has none. The following lists
83/* the macros and the types of the corresponding arguments.
84/* .IP "CA_MAIL_STREAM_CTL_QUEUE(const char *)"
85/* The argument specifies an alternate destination queue. The
86/* queue file is moved to the specified queue before the call
87/* returns. Failure to rename the queue file results in a fatal
88/* error.
89/* .IP "CA_MAIL_STREAM_CTL_CLASS(const char *)"
90/* The argument specifies an alternate trigger class.
91/* .IP "CA_MAIL_STREAM_CTL_SERVICE(const char *)"
92/* The argument specifies an alternate trigger service.
93/* .IP "CA_MAIL_STREAM_CTL_MODE(int)"
94/* The argument specifies alternate permissions that override
95/* the permissions specified with mail_stream_file().
96/* .IP "CA_MAIL_STREAM_CTL_DELAY(int)"
97/* Attempt to postpone initial delivery by advancing the queue
98/* file modification time stamp by this amount. This has
99/* effect only within the deferred mail queue.
100/* This feature may have no effect with remote file systems.
101/* LICENSE
102/* .ad
103/* .fi
104/* The Secure Mailer license must be distributed with this software.
105/* AUTHOR(S)
106/* Wietse Venema
107/* IBM T.J. Watson Research
108/* P.O. Box 704
109/* Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, USA
110/*--*/
111
112/* System library. */
113
114#include <sys_defs.h>
115#include <sys/stat.h>
116#include <unistd.h>
117#include <errno.h>
118#include <utime.h>
119#include <string.h>
120#include <stdarg.h>
121
122/* Utility library. */
123
124#include <msg.h>
125#include <mymalloc.h>
126#include <vstring.h>
127#include <vstream.h>
128#include <stringops.h>
129#include <argv.h>
130#include <sane_fsops.h>
131#include <warn_stat.h>
132
133/* Global library. */
134
135#include <cleanup_user.h>
136#include <mail_proto.h>
137#include <mail_queue.h>
138#include <opened.h>
139#include <mail_params.h>
140#include <mail_stream.h>
141#include <mail_parm_split.h>
142
143/* Application-specific. */
144
145static VSTRING *id_buf;
146
147#define FREE_AND_WIPE(free, arg) do { if (arg) free(arg); arg = 0; } while (0)
148
149#define STR(x) vstring_str(x)
150
151/* mail_stream_cleanup - clean up after success or failure */
152
153void mail_stream_cleanup(MAIL_STREAM *info)
154{
155 FREE_AND_WIPE(info->close, info->stream);
156 FREE_AND_WIPE(myfree, info->queue);
157 FREE_AND_WIPE(myfree, info->id);
158 FREE_AND_WIPE(myfree, info->class);
159 FREE_AND_WIPE(myfree, info->service);
160 myfree((void *) info);
161}
162
163#if defined(HAS_FUTIMES_AT)
164#define CAN_STAMP_BY_STREAM
165
166/* stamp_stream - update open file [am]time stamp */
167
168static int stamp_stream(VSTREAM *fp, time_t when)
169{
170 struct timeval tv[2];
171
172 if (when != 0) {
173 tv[0].tv_sec = tv[1].tv_sec = when;
174 tv[0].tv_usec = tv[1].tv_usec = 0;
175 return (futimesat(vstream_fileno(fp), (char *) 0, tv));
176 } else {
177 return (futimesat(vstream_fileno(fp), (char *) 0, (struct timeval *) 0));
178 }
179}
180
181#elif defined(HAS_FUTIMES)
182#define CAN_STAMP_BY_STREAM
183
184/* stamp_stream - update open file [am]time stamp */
185
186static int stamp_stream(VSTREAM *fp, time_t when)
187{
188 struct timeval tv[2];
189
190 if (when != 0) {
191 tv[0].tv_sec = tv[1].tv_sec = when;
192 tv[0].tv_usec = tv[1].tv_usec = 0;
193 return (futimes(vstream_fileno(fp), tv));
194 } else {
195 return (futimes(vstream_fileno(fp), (struct timeval *) 0));
196 }
197}
198
199#endif
200
201/* stamp_path - update file [am]time stamp by pathname */
202
203static int stamp_path(const char *path, time_t when)
204{
205 struct utimbuf tbuf;
206
207 if (when != 0) {
208 tbuf.actime = tbuf.modtime = when;
209 return (utime(path, &tbuf));
210 } else {
211 return (utime(path, (struct utimbuf *) 0));
212 }
213}
214
215/* mail_stream_finish_file - finish file mail stream */
216
217static int mail_stream_finish_file(MAIL_STREAM *info, VSTRING *unused_why)
218{
219 int status = CLEANUP_STAT_OK;
220 static char wakeup[] = {TRIGGER_REQ_WAKEUP};
221 struct stat st;
222 char *path_to_reset = 0;
223 static int incoming_fs_clock_ok = 0;
224 static int incoming_clock_warned = 0;
225 int check_incoming_fs_clock;
226 int err;
227 time_t want_stamp;
228 time_t expect_stamp;
229
230 /*
231 * Make sure the message makes it to file. Set the execute bit when no
232 * write error was detected. Some people believe that this code has a
233 * problem if the system crashes before fsync() returns; fchmod() could
234 * take effect before all the data blocks are written. Wietse claims that
235 * this is not a problem. Postfix rejects incomplete queue files, even
236 * when the +x attribute is set. Every Postfix queue file record has a
237 * type code and a length field. Files with missing records are rejected,
238 * as are files with unknown record type codes. Every Postfix queue file
239 * must end with an explicit END record. Postfix queue files without END
240 * record are discarded.
241 *
242 * Attempt to detect file system clocks that are ahead of local time, but
243 * don't check the file system clock all the time. The effect of file
244 * system clock drift can be difficult to understand (Postfix ignores new
245 * mail until the local clock catches up with the file mtime stamp).
246 *
247 * This clock drift detection code may not work with file systems that work
248 * on a local copy of the file and that update the server only after the
249 * file is closed.
250 *
251 * Optionally set a cooldown time.
252 *
253 * XXX: We assume that utime() does control the file modification time even
254 * when followed by an fchmod(), fsync(), close() sequence. This may fail
255 * with remote file systems when fsync() actually updates the file. Even
256 * then, we still delay the average message by 1/2 of the
257 * queue_run_delay.
258 *
259 * XXX: Victor does not like running utime() after the close(), since this
260 * creates a race even with local filesystems. But Wietse is not
261 * confident that utime() before fsync() and close() will work reliably
262 * with remote file systems.
263 *
264 * XXX Don't run the clock skew tests with Postfix sendmail submissions.
265 * Don't whine against unsuspecting users or applications.
266 */
267 check_incoming_fs_clock =
268 (!incoming_fs_clock_ok && !strcmp(info->queue, MAIL_QUEUE_INCOMING));
269
270#ifdef DELAY_ACTION
271 if (strcmp(info->queue, MAIL_QUEUE_DEFERRED) != 0)
272 info->delay = 0;
273 if (info->delay > 0)
274 want_stamp = time((time_t *) 0) + info->delay;
275 else
276#endif
277 want_stamp = 0;
278
279 /*
280 * If we can cheaply set the file time stamp (no pathname lookup) do it
281 * anyway, so that we can avoid whining later about file server/client
282 * clock skew.
283 *
284 * Otherwise, if we must set the file time stamp for delayed delivery, use
285 * whatever means we have to get the job done, no matter if it is
286 * expensive.
287 *
288 * XXX Unfortunately, Linux futimes() is not usable because it uses /proc.
289 * This may not be available because of chroot, or because of access
290 * restrictions after a process changes privileges.
291 */
292 if (vstream_fflush(info->stream)
293#ifdef CAN_STAMP_BY_STREAM
294 || stamp_stream(info->stream, want_stamp)
295#else
296 || (want_stamp && stamp_path(VSTREAM_PATH(info->stream), want_stamp))
297#endif
298 || fchmod(vstream_fileno(info->stream), 0700 | info->mode)
299#ifdef HAS_FSYNC
300 || fsync(vstream_fileno(info->stream))
301#endif
302 || (check_incoming_fs_clock
303 && fstat(vstream_fileno(info->stream), &st) < 0)
304 )
305 status = (errno == EFBIG ? CLEANUP_STAT_SIZE : CLEANUP_STAT_WRITE);
306#ifdef TEST
307 st.st_mtime += 10;
308#endif
309
310 /*
311 * Work around file system clock skew. If the file system clock is ahead
312 * of the local clock, Postfix won't deliver mail immediately, which is
313 * bad for performance. If the file system clock falls behind the local
314 * clock, it just looks silly in mail headers.
315 */
316 if (status == CLEANUP_STAT_OK && check_incoming_fs_clock) {
317 /* Do NOT use time() result from before fsync(). */
318 expect_stamp = want_stamp ? want_stamp : time((time_t *) 0);
319 if (st.st_mtime > expect_stamp) {
320 path_to_reset = mystrdup(VSTREAM_PATH(info->stream));
321 if (incoming_clock_warned == 0) {
322 msg_warn("file system clock is %d seconds ahead of local clock",
323 (int) (st.st_mtime - expect_stamp));
324 msg_warn("resetting file time stamps - this hurts performance");
325 incoming_clock_warned = 1;
326 }
327 } else {
328 if (st.st_mtime < expect_stamp - 100)
329 msg_warn("file system clock is %d seconds behind local clock",
330 (int) (expect_stamp - st.st_mtime));
331 incoming_fs_clock_ok = 1;
332 }
333 }
334
335 /*
336 * Close the queue file and mark it as closed. Be prepared for
337 * vstream_fclose() to fail even after vstream_fflush() and fsync()
338 * reported no error. Reason: after a file is closed, some networked file
339 * systems copy the file out to another machine. Running the queue on a
340 * remote file system is not recommended, if only for performance
341 * reasons.
342 */
343 err = info->close(info->stream);
344 info->stream = 0;
345 if (status == CLEANUP_STAT_OK && err != 0)
346 status = (errno == EFBIG ? CLEANUP_STAT_SIZE : CLEANUP_STAT_WRITE);
347
348 /*
349 * Work around file system clocks that are ahead of local time.
350 */
351 if (path_to_reset != 0) {
352 if (status == CLEANUP_STAT_OK) {
353 if (stamp_path(path_to_reset, expect_stamp) < 0 && errno != ENOENT)
354 msg_fatal("%s: update file time stamps: %m", info->id);
355 }
356 myfree(path_to_reset);
357 }
358
359 /*
360 * When all is well, notify the next service that a new message has been
361 * queued.
362 */
363 if (status == CLEANUP_STAT_OK && info->class && info->service)
364 mail_trigger(info->class, info->service, wakeup, sizeof(wakeup));
365
366 /*
367 * Cleanup.
368 */
369 mail_stream_cleanup(info);
370 return (status);
371}
372
373/* mail_stream_finish_ipc - finish IPC mail stream */
374
375static int mail_stream_finish_ipc(MAIL_STREAM *info, VSTRING *why)
376{
377 int status = CLEANUP_STAT_WRITE;
378
379 /*
380 * Receive the peer's completion status.
381 */
382 if ((why && attr_scan(info->stream, ATTR_FLAG_STRICT,
383 RECV_ATTR_INT(MAIL_ATTR_STATUS, &status),
384 RECV_ATTR_STR(MAIL_ATTR_WHY, why),
385 ATTR_TYPE_END) != 2)
386 || (!why && attr_scan(info->stream, ATTR_FLAG_MISSING,
387 RECV_ATTR_INT(MAIL_ATTR_STATUS, &status),
388 ATTR_TYPE_END) != 1))
389 status = CLEANUP_STAT_WRITE;
390
391 /*
392 * Cleanup.
393 */
394 mail_stream_cleanup(info);
395 return (status);
396}
397
398/* mail_stream_finish - finish action */
399
400int mail_stream_finish(MAIL_STREAM *info, VSTRING *why)
401{
402 return (info->finish(info, why));
403}
404
405/* mail_stream_file - destination is file */
406
407MAIL_STREAM *mail_stream_file(const char *queue, const char *class,
408 const char *service, int mode)
409{
410 struct timeval tv;
411 MAIL_STREAM *info;
412 VSTREAM *stream;
413
414 stream = mail_queue_enter(queue, 0600 | mode, &tv);
415 if (msg_verbose)
416 msg_info("open %s", VSTREAM_PATH(stream));
417
418 info = (MAIL_STREAM *) mymalloc(sizeof(*info));
419 info->stream = stream;
420 info->finish = mail_stream_finish_file;
421 info->close = vstream_fclose;
422 info->queue = mystrdup(queue);
423 info->id = mystrdup(basename(VSTREAM_PATH(stream)));
424 info->class = mystrdup(class);
425 info->service = mystrdup(service);
426 info->mode = mode;
427#ifdef DELAY_ACTION
428 info->delay = 0;
429#endif
430 info->ctime = tv;
431 return (info);
432}
433
434/* mail_stream_service - destination is service */
435
436MAIL_STREAM *mail_stream_service(const char *class, const char *name)
437{
438 VSTREAM *stream;
439 MAIL_STREAM *info;
440
441 if (id_buf == 0)
442 id_buf = vstring_alloc(10);
443
444 stream = mail_connect_wait(class, name);
445 if (attr_scan(stream, ATTR_FLAG_MISSING,
446 RECV_ATTR_STR(MAIL_ATTR_QUEUEID, id_buf), 0) != 1) {
447 vstream_fclose(stream);
448 return (0);
449 } else {
450 info = (MAIL_STREAM *) mymalloc(sizeof(*info));
451 info->stream = stream;
452 info->finish = mail_stream_finish_ipc;
453 info->close = vstream_fclose;
454 info->queue = 0;
455 info->id = mystrdup(vstring_str(id_buf));
456 info->class = 0;
457 info->service = 0;
458 return (info);
459 }
460}
461
462/* mail_stream_command - destination is command */
463
464MAIL_STREAM *mail_stream_command(const char *command)
465{
466 VSTREAM *stream;
467 MAIL_STREAM *info;
468 ARGV *export_env;
469 int status;
470
471 if (id_buf == 0)
472 id_buf = vstring_alloc(10);
473
474 /*
475 * Treat fork() failure as a transient problem. Treat bad handshake as a
476 * permanent error.
477 *
478 * XXX Are we invoking a Postfix process or a non-Postfix process? In the
479 * former case we can share the full environment; in the latter case only
480 * a restricted environment should be propagated. Even though we are
481 * talking a Postfix-internal protocol there is no way we can tell what
482 * is being executed except by duplicating a lot of existing code.
483 */
484 export_env = mail_parm_split(VAR_EXPORT_ENVIRON, var_export_environ);
485 while ((stream = vstream_popen(O_RDWR,
486 CA_VSTREAM_POPEN_COMMAND(command),
487 CA_VSTREAM_POPEN_EXPORT(export_env->argv),
488 CA_VSTREAM_POPEN_END)) == 0) {
489 msg_warn("fork: %m");
490 sleep(10);
491 }
492 argv_free(export_env);
493 vstream_control(stream,
494 CA_VSTREAM_CTL_PATH(command),
495 CA_VSTREAM_CTL_END);
496
497 if (attr_scan(stream, ATTR_FLAG_MISSING,
498 RECV_ATTR_STR(MAIL_ATTR_QUEUEID, id_buf), 0) != 1) {
499 if ((status = vstream_pclose(stream)) != 0)
500 msg_warn("command \"%s\" exited with status %d", command, status);
501 return (0);
502 } else {
503 info = (MAIL_STREAM *) mymalloc(sizeof(*info));
504 info->stream = stream;
505 info->finish = mail_stream_finish_ipc;
506 info->close = vstream_pclose;
507 info->queue = 0;
508 info->id = mystrdup(vstring_str(id_buf));
509 info->class = 0;
510 info->service = 0;
511 return (info);
512 }
513}
514
515/* mail_stream_ctl - update file-based mail stream properties */
516
517void mail_stream_ctl(MAIL_STREAM *info, int op,...)
518{
519 const char *myname = "mail_stream_ctl";
520 va_list ap;
521 char *new_queue = 0;
522 char *string_value;
523
524 /*
525 * Sanity check. None of the attributes below are applicable unless the
526 * target is a file-based stream.
527 */
528 if (info->finish != mail_stream_finish_file)
529 msg_panic("%s: attempt to update non-file stream %s",
530 myname, info->id);
531
532 for (va_start(ap, op); op != MAIL_STREAM_CTL_END; op = va_arg(ap, int)) {
533
534 switch (op) {
535
536 /*
537 * Change the queue directory. We do this at the end of this
538 * call.
539 */
540 case MAIL_STREAM_CTL_QUEUE:
541 if ((new_queue = va_arg(ap, char *)) == 0)
542 msg_panic("%s: NULL queue",
543 myname);
544 break;
545
546 /*
547 * Change the service that needs to be notified.
548 */
549 case MAIL_STREAM_CTL_CLASS:
550 FREE_AND_WIPE(myfree, info->class);
551 if ((string_value = va_arg(ap, char *)) != 0)
552 info->class = mystrdup(string_value);
553 break;
554
555 case MAIL_STREAM_CTL_SERVICE:
556 FREE_AND_WIPE(myfree, info->service);
557 if ((string_value = va_arg(ap, char *)) != 0)
558 info->service = mystrdup(string_value);
559 break;
560
561 /*
562 * Change the (finished) file access mode.
563 */
564 case MAIL_STREAM_CTL_MODE:
565 info->mode = va_arg(ap, int);
566 break;
567
568 /*
569 * Advance the (finished) file modification time.
570 */
571#ifdef DELAY_ACTION
572 case MAIL_STREAM_CTL_DELAY:
573 if ((info->delay = va_arg(ap, int)) < 0)
574 msg_panic("%s: bad delay time %d", myname, info->delay);
575 break;
576#endif
577
578 default:
579 msg_panic("%s: bad op code %d", myname, op);
580 }
581 }
582 va_end(ap);
583
584 /*
585 * Rename the queue file after allocating memory for new information, so
586 * that the caller can still remove an embryonic file when memory
587 * allocation fails (there is no risk of deleting the wrong file).
588 *
589 * Wietse opposed the idea to update run-time error handler information
590 * here, because this module wasn't designed to defend against internal
591 * concurrency issues with error handlers that attempt to follow dangling
592 * pointers.
593 *
594 * This code duplicates mail_queue_rename(), except that we need the new
595 * path to update the stream pathname.
596 */
597 if (new_queue != 0 && strcmp(info->queue, new_queue) != 0) {
598 char *saved_queue = info->queue;
599 char *saved_path = mystrdup(VSTREAM_PATH(info->stream));
600 VSTRING *new_path = vstring_alloc(100);
601
602 (void) mail_queue_path(new_path, new_queue, info->id);
603 info->queue = mystrdup(new_queue);
604 vstream_control(info->stream, CA_VSTREAM_CTL_PATH(STR(new_path)),
605 CA_VSTREAM_CTL_END);
606
607 if (sane_rename(saved_path, STR(new_path)) == 0
608 || (mail_queue_mkdirs(STR(new_path)) == 0
609 && sane_rename(saved_path, STR(new_path)) == 0)) {
610 if (msg_verbose)
611 msg_info("%s: placed in %s queue", info->id, info->queue);
612 } else {
613 msg_fatal("%s: move to %s queue failed: %m", info->id,
614 info->queue);
615 }
616
617 myfree(saved_path);
618 myfree(saved_queue);
619 vstring_free(new_path);
620 }
621}
